Message.Msg: For all of those who rant and rave either on the Left or Right, I would suggest you might consider the recent events with HSBC as proof that the American political parties are bought and paid for and as SERVENTS of the rich no longer repersent your best interests. HSBC worked with the Mexican Drug Loards to Laundry massive amounts of money and violated mult. sanctions , all in order to fill their pockets with profit. These actions were taken will full knowledge of the Management of HSBC. No one went to jail and they only had to pay a large fine for their activity. So. consider this if anyone that was not rich or powerful had been caught selling $100 of dope would they have only received a fine? If you were supporting the terrorist nations would you only received a fine? If you activity support the murder of 100's would you have received a fine? It is past time for the SHEEP of this nation awoke to the fact that they are being led to thier own doom by the rich and powerful and neither party has any interest in repersenting them. The issues that the con men utlize to divert you from the realization that your goverment has no real concern for you will never be addressed unless it can be used to increase the wealth of the few. Wake-up, unite and demand election reform that will return the goverment to the people.

Topic.Title: Republicns want to do away with SS trust fund

Message.Msg: The SS trust fund is very much de facto part of the general fund as that is where the payroll taxes go that don't go to retireees. But if one ignores the $25 trillion future liabilities of the SS fund for which there is no current savings then the financial state of the SS fund is just peachy. To think the SS fund is OK is a dangerous delusion that will become an ugly reality down the road.

Message.Title: Our Week of 3/9/13
Message.Msg: "Early during This week of the 10th, G F Will, quoting Mitchell McConnell of the GOP Senate minority leadership, said, “The more revenue question—it is settled.” Debbie Wassermann Schultz, Fl House member and leader of DNC, claimed “We have paralyzed GOP leadership, especially in the House.” Paul Krugman, commenting about dinner meetings with the GOP, claims such gatherings are pointless because the two parties have two fundamentally different visions of government role;however it does satisfy, to a certain extent, Mr. Obama's need for elitist flitting about squandering money on excess. Krugman considers raising eligibility age for Medicaid terrible policy and a money drain and he would favor means testing for Medicaid; we feel he might mean "medicare", here. Wassermann Schultz would favor entitlement reforms, if coupled with a “balanced approach”, meaning added revenue by higher taxes, and 'my way or the highway'. Hyphenated names are passing tedious. Past Fla gov J E B Bush considers “sustained economic growth’ the way to deal with the need for added govt income. He feels “coming out of the shadows” is good for illegal immigrants, although it hardly replaces obeying the laws of the country you have invaded. He argues that citizenship should not be granted to illegals ahead of those who have arrived legally. Which kind of means 'never', co Brief mention of the Sen Rand Paul filibuster included the narrator saying “Sen Paul will run for the presidency in 2016.” Brief mention, too, of the Sheryl Sandberg book, with Wassermann Schultz praising her husband (assumed, name ends with Schultz) for his help with her family and career worries,,,her words including praise of his employer. New feature—Sunday spotlight—a few minutes of interview of past v p Richard Cheney, a man said to be “invested in his legacy". Sponsors, fewer—BP and :PacLife and GE and Chevron, also ETrade and Xerox. One member of USA military, age 22 from Ohio, made the ultimate

Topic.Title: Republicns want to do away with SS trust fund

Message.Msg: Republicans have always been after ss. President Johnson put ss in the general fund but he planed on paying it back 'Pay Back Social Security -- The Government Has Borrowed More from Social Security than any Other Entity or Foreign Government Another argument made by Social Security opponents to raise fear about the national debt is how much our government has borrowed from China. They never mention how much our government has borrowed from Social Security. In fact, the government has borrowed more from the Social Security surplus than it has from any other source in the world, including China. As a result, Social Security now "owns" nearly 18 percent of the federal debt, making it the largest single holder of US debt. The government owes almost twice as much to Social Security as it does to China and Hong Kong. Why aren't the opponents worried about paying back Social Security -- why aren't they talking about repaying this debt to the American people? According to the U.S. Treasury Department's "Monthly Statement of the Public Debt of the United States" (9.30.10), the total debt was $13.562 trillion and was held as follows: US Holders of Debt 42.1 % -- US Individuals and Institutions 17.9 % -- Social Security Trust Fund 6.0 % -- US Civil Service Retirement Fund 2.1 % -- US Military Retirement Fund Foreign Holders of Debt 11.7 % -- Oil Exporting Countries 9.5 % -- China and Hong Kong 6.3 % -- Japan 1.4 % -- United Kingdom 1.3 % -- Brazil 1.6 % -- All other foreign countries

Message.Title: The Fed’s approval on these banks’
Message.Msg: Banks Triumph Over Stress Test: Bank of America Corp (BAC), Citigroup Inc. (C), Morgan Stanley (MS) March 8th, 2013Goto commentsLeave a comment 2 share0 Zacks: On Thursday, the Federal Reserve released the Dodd-Frank Act supervisory stress test 2013 (DFAST 2013) results, which reflects stability in the banking system to a great extent. Actually, this confirms the ability of U.S. banking giants to survive under a tremendously difficult economic scenario. Among 18 bank holding companies which submitted their capital plan to the Fed in Jan 2013, the auto lender, Ally Financial, majority-owned by U.S. taxpayers, failed to meet the minimum requirement of 5% Tier 1 common capital ratio. With 1.5% capital ratio, Ally remains unstable, struggling with troubled mortgages and other distressed businesses. However, the remaining 17 banks that have capital ratio above 5% now have the privilege to alter their capital plans within 48 hours from the time of this result release. The Fed’s approval on these banks’ capital plans is expected on Mar 14.

Topic.Title: Can someone remind me...
Republicns want to do away with SS trust fund

Message.Msg: Those "debts" are simply IOU's of the gov't in the SS fund. In 1960, the US supreme court in Fleming Vs Nestor held that workers had no legally binding contractual obligation to their social security benefits. Which is to say, the IOU's are not backed by the full faith and credit of the US. Better provide for your own retirement if your 40.

Topic.Title: Can I Default on a BAC Mortgage and Say I Just Forgot?

Message.Msg: yes, Wonder how Americans can afford to buy millions of iGadgets, a second LCD TV for the shoe closet, and eat at restaurants more than almost any time in the past despite sliding personal income? Simple - increasingly fewer pay the biggest staple bill in a US household: their mortgage. The following story of Keith And Janet Ritter, who have lived in their Fort Washington, MD $1.29MM, 4,900 square foot McMansion for 5 years (which they purchase with no money down) without ever making a single mortgage payment, and who are not even close to being evicted, may explain much about the way US society currently operates, and why other perfectly responsible and hard-working taxpayers (who do have to pay for their mortgage) continue to fund tens of billions in Fannie and Freddie losses who are first on the hook to absorb the implicit losses by allowing families such as the Ritters to live in perpetuity without paying, and the banks to keep said mortgage on the books at par without any impairments.

Message.Title: Boosted by a strong employment numbers
Message.Msg: Boosted by a strong employment numbers, the Dow Jones Industrial Average 2 Minute (Dow Jones Indices: .DJI) made further gains today, finishing up 33 points, or 0.2%. Initial unemployment claims last week dropped to 340,000, a five-year low, down from 347,000 the week before, and better than analyst estimates of 350,000. Continuing claims were also near a five-year low, at 3.094 million. Data on the international trade balance and productivity were roughly in line with expectations. The Federal Reserve also released the results of its stress tests on the nation's largest banks, and said that in the aggregate, the 18 banks hold fewer bad loans than they did a year ago, and are stronger than they've been at any time since the financial crisis. Ally Financial, the former financial wing of General Motors, was the poorest performer. Next week, the Fed will decide if it will approve the banks' plans to return capital to shareholders via share buybacks and dividends. Not surprisingly, Bank of America Corp (NYSE:BAC) reacted well in the run-up to the Fed report, which was released after hours, as it gained 2.9% on the day. The results showed B of A would lose $44 billion, or 2.3% of its total assets, over the next nine quarters under the Fed's worst scenario, which includes the unemployment rate jumping to 12%, and the Dow getting cut in half. According to the test, the bank is capitalized well enough to survive such a scenario. Shares were down 0.6% after hours. JPMorgan Chase & Co. (NYSE:JPM) was also a strong performer on the day, gaining 1.2%. The Boeing Company (NYSE:BA) shares also jumped 2.5%, as Ray Conner, the CEO of the manufacturer's commercial airplanes division, said that a solution to the battery fires should come "in weeks, not months." Other reports today showed that the company had considered the risk of a battery fire nearly impossible during the 787's design and production phase. Oddly, shares of the aerospace-maker reached a 52-week high, even as delays in delivery and possible blowback airlines, including one that recently sued The Boeing Company (NYSE:BA), could hurt profits. Topic.Title: Republicns want to do away with SS trust fund

Message.Msg: Correct. It is not part of the general fund. Congress has borrowed from our savings account and would now like to agree not to pay us back by cutting this "entitlement". Social security is a separate tax and goes in to a separate fund and is owed enough by the government via Government bonds to pay it's bills for the next 20 years at least. Some congressmen believe it should be treated as just another item in the general fund budget. One was on Kents favorite news program this morning.

Message.Msg: The tale of the tickers But before we get to the hows and whys of B of A's big week, let's take a quick look at where its peers and the market overall are shaking out for the week: Up by a massive 8.71%, Citigroup Inc. (NYSE:C) has had an even better week than B of A. JPMorgan Chase & Co. (NYSE:JPM) looks set to finish up just a little more than two percentage points, at 2.29%. Wells Fargo & Co (NYSE:WFC) is up almost three points, currently at 2.78%. All three major indices are in the green, as well: The S&P 500 is up 2.23%. The Dow is up 2.32%. And the Nasdaq is up 2.48%. Fingers more than crossed for buybacks and dividends We have two separate happenings playing into B of A's big performance this week. First, we're in a bull moment right now overall. The Dow hit a new all-time high this week. Investor confidence is obviously strong, and when investors see other investors jumping into the market, they want to follow suit. As indices drive higher, more investors plunk their money down. And as more investors plunk their money down, indices are driven higher, which draw more investors in. Energy -- whether positive or negative -- attracts like energy. The second big happening relates to Federal Reserve stress test results. Bank investors have been on collective pins and needles waiting to see how their banks will perform, and whether or not said banks will engage in a fresh round of share buybacks or increased dividends.
